Facilitating the "Creative Coding with Scratch" workshop at the Nyanza Initiative for Girls Education and
Empowerment (NIGEE) in Kisumu was one of the most rewarding experiences of my professional
journey. The workshop, organized by a dynamic team of facilitators from various STEM organizations,
aimed to introduce educators to Scratch programming while equipping them with creative coding
techniques to make learning more engaging for their students. My role was not only to guide the
participants through the learning process but also to ensure they felt empowered to implement these
new skills in their classrooms.
Workshop Preparations and Planning

The month leading up to the workshop was a crucial phase of intense preparation and collaboration. As
facilitators, we conducted baseline surveys to assess participants' familiarity with coding and their
access to technology. The results revealed a significant gap—most educators had limited experience
with Scratch and faced challenges like unreliable internet connectivity and a lack of personal laptops.
These findings shaped our approach, driving us to focus on offline Scratch use and securing resources,
such as laptops from Fablab Kisumu, to bridge technological gaps.
Interactive Workshop Sessions

The workshop itself was a lively and interactive experience. One of the most memorable activities was
the "Human Robot Game" where participants acted as robots and programmers to understand coding
logic. The laughter and teamwork during this session set the tone for the workshop, breaking the ice and
making coding concepts approachable. Many participants shared that this activity helped them see
coding as less intimidating and more fun—a mindset they could pass on to their students.
Another highlight was the guided exploration of Scratch’s interface. For many participants, this was their
first exposure to coding, and their initial hesitancy quickly turned into excitement as they discovered
how to use Scratch blocks, sprites, and backdrops. It was inspiring to watch as educators, some of whom
had never used a computer for creative purposes, began creating simple animations and interactive
projects.
The collaborative team projects further showcased the participants’ growth. Teachers from diverse
backgrounds worked together to create Scratch projects tied to their curriculum. One group designed an
animation to teach geometric shapes, while another created an interactive quiz on environmental
conservation. Seeing their ideas come to life reinforced the power of collaboration and creativity in
problem-solving.
Impact and Reflection

The impact of the workshop was evident during the final session, where participants presented their
Scratch projects. The pride and excitement in their voices as they explained how they would integrate
these projects into their lessons were palpable. One teacher shared that she planned to use Scratch to
create interactive storytelling activities for her students, while another expressed enthusiasm about
starting a student coding club.
Feedback from participants underscored the success of the workshop. Over 90% reported increased
confidence in using Scratch, and many requested advanced training to deepen their skills. For me, this
was a clear indication that the workshop had not only met its objectives but also inspired educators to
continue exploring creative coding.
Personal Takeaways

As a facilitator, this experience deepened my understanding of the challenges and opportunities in
integrating technology into education. It reaffirmed the importance of designing training programs that
are inclusive and adaptable to diverse needs. The collaborative spirit of the workshop—among
facilitators, participants, and supporting organizations—highlighted the power of community in driving
educational innovation.
Most importantly, this workshop reinforced my belief in the transformative potential of creative coding.
Watching educators who were initially hesitant about technology grow confident and excited about
using Scratch in their classrooms was incredibly rewarding. It reminded me why I am passionate about
STEM education: it empowers both teachers and students to think creatively, solve problems, and
imagine new possibilities.

In conclusion, the Creative Coding with Scratch workshop was not just a professional milestone but
also a personal one. It provided me with valuable insights into the needs of educators and the impact of
creative coding in the classroom. As I reflect on this experience, I am motivated to continue supporting
educators in their journey toward innovative and engaging teaching.
Overcoming Challenges

Like any learning experience, the workshop was not without its challenges. One of the main hurdles was
the participants’ varying levels of familiarity with technology. While some teachers quickly adapted to
Scratch, others struggled with the basics. To address this, we implemented peer mentoring, pairing
participants with more tech-savvy colleagues. This approach not only improved learning outcomes but
also fostered a supportive environment.
Another challenge was the limited time for project development. With so much to cover in a short
period, participants often felt rushed. To mitigate this, we introduced self-paced learning resources and
encouraged participants to continue exploring Scratch after the workshop. We also emphasized that
their initial projects were just the beginning of a longer journey in creative coding.
The issue of unreliable internet connectivity was particularly significant, as it hindered access to online
resources. However, by emphasizing Scratch's offline capabilities and providing downloadable materials,
we ensured that participants could continue learning and teaching coding regardless of their internet
access.

For many, the mention of mathematics conjures images of complex equations, abstract theories, and perhaps a lingering sense of frustration. I know this feeling well. Growing up in Kenya, mathematics wasn't a subject that came easily to me. I was often the student who needed extra time, struggling to grasp concepts and feeling overwhelmed by problem-solving while my classmates seemed to navigate numbers with effortless ease. However, my journey took an unexpected turn, guided by the belief of one exceptional teacher and now blossoming into a mission to make mathematics an exciting adventure for young minds through innovative math camps, often conducted in collaboration with the esteemed African Maths Initiative (AMI).
The Shadow of Numbers.

My early years in mathematics, from Form One at Loreto High School Limuru, were marked by a persistent struggle. Concepts that seemed intuitive to my peers often felt like insurmountable hurdles for me. The pace of the classroom sometimes left me behind, and the stark contrast between my understanding and that of the "bright" and "fast" learners around me often chipped away at my confidence. Mathematics felt like an exclusive club, and I was on the outside looking in.
A Beacon of Belief: Mr. Martin Ng'aru.

Everything began to shift when I encountered Mr. Martin Ng'aru in Form Three at Loreto High School Limuru. He wasn't just a mathematics teacher; he was a beacon of belief. Taking over from my previous teacher, he recognized my struggles and went above and beyond, willingly offering me private consultations and tailoring his explanations to my learning pace. He never made me feel inadequate for needing extra help. Instead, he patiently guided me, breaking down complex ideas into manageable steps. What resonated most was his unwavering belief in my potential. He saw beyond my current grades and instilled in me the conviction that I could do better. And slowly, but surely, as I learned at my own rhythm under his tutelage, my grades began to reflect that newfound belief. Mr. Ng'aru didn't just teach me math; he taught me to believe in myself.
From Classroom to Camp: A Mission Inspired.

After teaching in two sub-county schools within Kakamega County for about three years, I felt a pull towards a broader mission – to tackle the very challenges I had faced as a student. This led me to join Innovations in Development, Education and Mathematical Sciences (INNODEMS). Working hand in hand with the African Maths Initiative (AMI), INNODEMS' core focus on demystifying mathematics education for primary and high school students deeply resonated with me. It felt like a chance to pay forward the transformative impact Mr. Ng'aru had on my life, now on a larger scale through collaborative efforts with AMI.

My first experience with this approach came during the STEM Youth Boot Camp in Arusha, Tanzania. Witnessing the enthusiasm of students who attended our mathematics sessions, facilitated jointly with AMI principles, was incredibly inspiring. The positive feedback, the genuine excitement they expressed about learning math in a new and engaging way, solidified my belief in this approach. It was a stark contrast to the anxiety I once felt towards the subject.
Impacting Thousands: Math Camps Across Kenya and Beyond.

Since its inception, INNODEMS has successfully facilitated 21 impactful mathematics camps both within Kenya and in neighboring countries. These camps have reached thousands of students, fostering a more positive and engaging relationship with mathematics. Two camps that particularly stand out in my memory are: one held at Siburi Mixed Secondary School in Homabay County, which brought together an impressive 317 students from 7 different schools, and another at Rombo Girls Secondary School in Oloitoktok, where we had the privilege of working with a remarkable 645 enthusiastic students. These large-scale events underscore the significant reach and impact of our collaborative efforts with AMI and our dedication to transforming mathematics education.
A Comprehensive Understanding: Feedback from the Ground and Supporting Math Clubs.

The true impact of our work at INNODEMS, often in partnership with AMI, is gleaned through multiple channels of feedback. Beyond the quantitative data from our entry and exit surveys, we place significant value on the qualitative insights shared by students at the end of each daily session. Guided by questions like, "What was your key/main takeaway today? What do you wonder? And do you have any suggestions for improvement?", these reflections provide a rich and nuanced understanding of the barriers and enablers of mathematics education within diverse contexts. This comprehensive approach allows us to tailor our interventions effectively and witness genuine transformations in students' attitudes and understanding. Furthermore, INNODEMS develops and provides resources to support thriving Math Clubs in schools, fostering a continuous engagement with the subject beyond our camps. We are also actively working closely with schools within Kakamega County, including Kakamega Comprehensive School, to provide ongoing support and implement effective mathematics learning strategies.
The Joy of Discovery: Math Camps in Action.

The collective data and reflections consistently reveal the positive impact of our math camps. We witness students exceeding their own expectations, their initial apprehension replaced by a newfound confidence and even joy in tackling mathematical problems. These success stories, often marked by a simple comment like, "I never thought math could be this fun!" or insightful reflections on newfound understanding, are the fuel that drives our mission with INNODEMS and our collaboration with AMI.
A Call to Engage and Inspire.

My journey, from a student struggling with the basics to someone actively working to make mathematics accessible and enjoyable through INNODEMS and our partnership with AMI, has taught me a crucial lesson: learning mathematics should be an adventure, not an ordeal. My hope is to inspire students to see mathematics not just as a subject filled with rules and formulas, but as a fascinating concept that helps us understand the world around us.

To my fellow educators, I urge you to make the learning of mathematics engaging and enjoyable.
